access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a non-fillable 2-page PDF patient access form for the hospital (form-3) or medical group (form-2), prints and fills by hand, then mails or faxes it to the HIM department.

red_flags: Physician approval required for patient access to own HIV test results
Caregiver approval required for patient access to own psychiatric records
Physician notification/veto mechanism built into standard patient access workflow (form-3)
Form-2 demands in-person photo ID presentation while offering remote submission options
bright_spots: Clear separation of patient access from third-party release with explicit cross-references between forms
Multiple electronic delivery format options including USB drive, CD, secure and unsecured email, flash drive
Inspect-only option available (form-2) allowing record review without copying fees
Direct department contact information (phone, fax, email) prominently displayed on form-2

findability.rationale: Level 4: Forms were easy to find via web search and linked from the Dignity Health Sacramento medical records page; minor friction from dual-track (hospital vs. medical group) structure that requires patients to identify which entity holds their records.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 2: Both patient access forms have zero fillable fields, requiring a print-and-handwrite workflow; the hospital form (form-3) provides only mailing addresses for submission, making this primarily a paper workflow despite form-2 listing fax/email contact info for the medical group department.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Forms are organized with lettered sections and checkboxes at an appropriate 2-page length, but form-3 has severe font encoding corruption impairing screen reader accessibility, the date range is framed as 'hospitalization' rather than general dates, and fee amounts are undisclosed.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: Dedicated patient access forms exist and are clearly separated from third-party authorization, but the dual-track structure requires patients to determine hospital vs. medical group, physician gatekeeping provisions undermine patient autonomy, and no patient rights statement is included on either access form.

compliance.rationale: Level 2: Physician approval requirements for patient access to own HIV and psychiatric records likely exceed HIPAA Right of Access limits; the physician notification/veto mechanism on form-3 creates an illegitimate barrier; no appeal rights or reviewing professional process disclosed as required by 45 CFR ยง 164.524(d)(4).

overall.summary: Mercy General Hospital provides dedicated patient access forms separate from third-party authorization with flexible delivery options, but non-fillable PDFs, physician gatekeeping provisions, and a confusing dual-track structure substantially undermine the patient experience.
